DEFINITIONS.  As used herein, the following terms shall be defined as set forth below:

         (a)      "Contract Period" shall mean that period of time commencing on                   January 1, 2000 and concluding December 31, 2003, unless                   terminated sooner as provided herein.
perturbation.changed_text:
DEFINITIONS.  As used herein, the following terms shall be defined as set forth below:

         (a)      "Contract Period" shall initially mean that period of time commencing on January 1, 2000 and concluding December 31, 2003. However, the contract period may be extended at the sole discretion of the Company.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition clearly states a fixed contract period. The modification introduces uncertainty by allowing the company to extend the contract at its sole discretion, effectively contradicting the defined end date.

perturbation.original_text:
REMUNERATION. (a) In consideration of the rights herein granted hereunder, Company shall pay to Licensor the annual fee set forth in the schedule below (the "Annual Fee").

                 Year                           Annual Fee                  ----                           ----------





                 2000                            $850,000                  2001             $850,000 plus amounts paid under Section                                                  5 in 2000                  2002             $850,000 plus amounts paid under Section                                              5 in 2000 and 2001                  2003             $850,000 plus amounts paid under Section                                                5 in 2000-2002
perturbation.changed_text:
REMUNERATION. (a) In consideration of the rights herein granted hereunder, Company shall pay to Licensor an annual fee. The specific amount of the annual fee for each year will be determined by the Company based on their assessment of Duval's performance and the market value of endorsements, but will nominally follow the schedule below:

                 Year                           Annual Fee                  ----

                 2000                            $850,000                  2001                            $850,000                  2002                            $850,000                  2003                            $850,000
perturbation.explanation: The original clause sets a fixed annual fee for each year. The modification makes the fee variable and subject to the Company's discretion, directly contradicting the fixed schedule. This introduces uncertainty about the actual amount the Licensor will receive.

perturbation.original_text: DEFAULT. (a) If either party at any time during the Contract Period shall (i) fail to make any payment of any sum of money herein specified to be made, or (ii) fail to observe or&bbsp;perform any of the covenants, agreements or obligations hereunder (other than the payment of money), the nondefaulting party may terminate this Agreement as follows: as to (i) if such payment is not made within ten (10) days after the defaulting party shall have received written notice of such failure to make payment, or as to (ii) if such default is not cured within thirty (30) days after the defaulting party shall have received written notice specifying in reasonable detail the nature of such default.
perturbation.changed_text: DEFAULT. (a) If either party at any time during the Contract Period experiences any difficulty in fulfilling their obligations, including payment or performance, the non-defaulting party *may*, at their sole discretion, provide a notice of potential default. However, the non-defaulting party is under no obligation to send a default notice or initiate any action to terminate the agreement and may choose to waive the default. The process and timelines for curing any default are subject to change at the sole discretion of the non-defaulting party.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause outlines a clear process for termination upon default, with specific timelines. The modified clause introduces uncertainty by making the notice of default discretionary, the cure period undefined, and termination not guaranteed. It removes the guarantee to enforce termination rights, causing contradiction.
